Special Features 

Many  low-income  households  rely  on  remittances  to  meet  basic 
needs.  About  100,000  migrant  workers  returned  to  Tajikistan 
during  the  first  quarter  of  2009,  and  many  more  are  expected  in 
the coming months. Unemployment, which is already estimated to 
be about 40%, is likely to rise sharply as a result of the economic 
slowdown, as well as the large influx of migrant workers. Poverty 
and social impacts of the crisis will be direct and immediate.   
 
The  need  for  countercyclical  fiscal  policies  and  social  safety  net 
measures  is  urgent.  However,  lack  of  fiscal  space—exacerbated 
by  the  crisis—constrains  the  Government's  ability  to  implement 
such measures. 
 
The  Tajikistan  Crisis  Recovery  Support  Program  will  provide 
short-term  fiscal  stimulus  to  mitigate  the  economic  and  social 
impact  of  the  crisis.  The  program  will  help  meet  critical  public 
expenditures  such  as  social  allowances,  employment  programs, 
subventions  to  poor  regions,  and  the  food,  medicine  and  utility 
expenses of social institutions.  
 
The program is fully in line with the Government's crisis mitigation 
program.  In  the  revised  2009  budget,  the  Government  has 
prioritized  specific  social  and  safety  net  expenditures.  Program 
proceeds  will  help  meet  some  of 
the  prioritized  public 
expenditures.

Tajikistan  has  been  severely  affected  by  the  crisis.  The  program 
will  support Government  efforts  to  cushion  the adverse  impact  of 
the  crisis  through  appropriate  fiscal  policies  and  safety  net 
programs.  The  immediate  beneficiaries  will  be  the  poor  and 
vulnerable groups who are hardest hit by the crisis.  
 
There  are  three  main  risks.  First,  the  global  downturn  could  be 
more  protracted  than  anticipated.  Continuing  deterioration  in  the 
global  economic  situation—and  particularly  the  outlook  for  the 
Russian  Federation  and  Kazakhstan—could  lead  to  more  severe 
impacts  on  Tajikistan’s  economy.  Second,  rising  uncertainty  and 
competing  needs  and  priorities  could  slow  the  Government’s 
implementation of appropriate policy responses. 
 
The  Government  has  been  proactive 
its 
macroeconomic stabilization and countercyclical fiscal policies. In 
November 2008, the Government established the inter-ministerial 
crisis  management  committee  (ICMC)  chaired  by  the  Prime 
Minister.  The  ICMC  has  adopted  a  crisis  management  plan 
covering  monetary,  fiscal  and  financial  sector  policies  and  social 
safety  net  programs.  Within  the  ICMC  framework,  MOF  has 
finalized  the  revised  2009  budget  to  reflect  the  revenue  shortfall 
and expenditure priorities.  
 
Development  partners  have  responded  quickly  with  policy  advice 
and financial assistance. To meet the balance-of-payments needs 
arising  from  the  crisis,  the  IMF  recently  approved  a  $116  million 
PRGF.  The  World  Bank  has  approved  $20  million  in  budget 
support under the Third Programmatic Development Policy Grant 
in March 2009. The European Commission is also taking steps to 
fast-track  disbursement  under  two  ongoing  projects  to  provide 
budget support in 2009.   
 
A  third  risk  is  that  poor  design  and  weak  fiduciary  controls  may 
hamper  the  efficacy  of  the  crisis  mitigation  plans.  The  program 
design  is  straightforward  and  there  is  no  complex  targeting  or 
identification  of  beneficiaries  involved.  ADB,  in  collaboration  with 
the other development partners, will work with the Government in 
adhering to good financial management practices in executing the 
crisis mitigation program.

B. 

Short-Term Challenges: Impact of the Global Financial Crisis 

6. 
In 2009, the severe impact of the global financial crisis presents an immediate challenge 
to  Tajikistan.  Without  adequate  mitigating  measures,  Tajikistan  will  be  unable  to  sustain 
macroeconomic stability and contain the impact on the poor and vulnerable.  
 
7. 
Poverty  and  Social  Impact.  The  effect  of  the  crisis  in  terms  of  poverty  and  social 
impacts will be direct and immediate. A 2007 Asian Development Bank (ADB) survey indicated 
that  as  many  as  40%  of  all  households  and  71%  of  households  in  the  lowest  quintile  receive 
remittances.3 Low-income households use remittances to meet basic needs. Unemployment will 
likely rise sharply as a result of the economic slowdown, as well as the large influx of migrant 
workers. The Government's social assistance programs are likewise at risk of being curtailed as 
the global financial crisis reduces fiscal resources (Appendix 2). 
 
8. 
Remittances and Exports.  The global financial crisis and economic downturn will have 
a  significant  impact  on  remittances.  Remittances  from  Tajik  overseas  migrant  workers  have 
surged  in  recent  years  and  peaked  at  $2.6  billion  (50%  of  GDP)  in  late  2008  (Figure  1). 
Remittance-linked  consumption  and  construction  have  propelled  domestic  demand  and 
economic growth.

13. 
Near-Term Outlook.  Tajikistan's  near-term  economic  outlook  has  deteriorated 
considerably. The IMF estimates that there will be 2% growth in real GDP in 2009, down from 
8% in 2008. The IMF also emphasizes that there is considerable downside risk to this outlook. 
The  current  account  deficit  for  2009  is  projected  to  reach  10%  of  GDP.  Foreign  direct 
investment  will  decline  from  the  already  low  level  of  $190  million  to  $100  million  in  2009.  Net 
international reserves are currently precariously low ($170 million), covering less than 1 month 
of imports. The IMF estimates a balance-of-payment financing gap of $154 million for 2009. The 
official unemployment rate is 2%, but actual unemployment and underemployment are believed 
to  be  as  high  as  40%.  The  unemployment  rate  will  rise  sharply  as  the  economy  slows  and 
migrant workers return in significant numbers.   
 
14. 
Tax  revenues  have  declined  as  a  result  of  the  economic  slowdown,  and  because 
remittance-linked  imports  account  for  60%  of  total  revenues  (Appendix  3).  The  authorities  are

economy, and impose hardship on the population.

other  social  insurance  benefits  (e.g.,  unemployment  benefits  for  6  months,  disability  and 
maternity allowances) for those who have contributed to the social protection fund are covered 
by the fund, with non-contributors covered by the republican and local budgets. Expenditures for 
the  education  and  health  sectors  are  supported  by  the  republican  and  local  budgets,  with 
general  education  and  primary  and  secondary  health  services  financed  by  the  local  budget, 
while higher education and tertiary health services are financed by the republican budget.  
 
4.

infrastructure  and  personnel.  The  education  sector  has  about  4,500  education  and  research

catering  to  inpatient  and  outpatient  services  for  the  entire  population  of  Tajikistan,  and 
preventive services that include (most importantly) immunization for children.

TAX STRUCTURE 

 
1. 
There are 15 state taxes and four local taxes in Tajikistan. The value-added tax (VAT) 
accounts for more than half of total tax collections (Tables A3.1 and A3.2). A large part of VAT 
collection is from imports. The second tier of taxes (in term of share of total tax collections) are 
the  income  and  profit  taxes  (13%  of  tax  revenues)  and  social  taxes  (11%  of  tax  revenues). 
Social  taxes  are  not  general  revenue,  as  they  accrue  to  the  Social  Protection  Fund.  The 
importance of the VAT in terms of tax revenues and the large differential between the VAT and 
the  second  tier  taxes  may  be  attributed  to  the  heavy  dependence  of  Tajikistan’s  economy  on 
migrant  worker  remittances.  Remittances  fuel  consumption  spending,  which  includes  a  large 
proportion of imported goods. Coverage of remittance inflows by direct taxes—such as income, 
profit  and  social  taxes—is  poor.  VAT’s  share  of  tax  revenues  is  also  high  because  of  the 
relatively high VAT rate. Sales taxes are levied on key commodities like cotton fibers (10% rate) 
and  aluminum  (3%).  Together  with  the  retail  sales  tax  accruing  to  local  governments,  these 
indirect taxes account for about 4.6% of total revenues. Customs duties account for just 5.9% of 
tax revenue.

Tax Administration. Taxation in Tajikistan is governed by the Tax Code, Customs Code 
2. 
and  Law  on  Customs  Tariff.  Administration  of  both  state  and  local  internal  taxes  is  under  the 
purview  of  the  Tax  Committee,  while  customs  duties,  VAT,  and  excise  taxes  on  imports  are 
collected  by  a  separate  customs  service.  There  have  been  limited  reforms  in  the  tax  system, 
including  the  introduction  of  the  Large  Taxpayers  Inspectorate  (LTI).  With  donor-support, 
functional reorganization has been undertaken in the LTI. The adoption of the new tax code in 
2005 was one attempt to reform taxation but it is hampered by implementation gaps as well as 
some subsequent amendments. 
 
3. 
Tax  administration  is  governed  by  a  regionalized  structure.  Excluding  large  taxpayer 
payments (which fall under the LTI), state and local taxes are administered regionally by the Tax 
Committee  through  its  city,  oblast  and  raion  offices.  While  the  Tax  Committee  is  ultimately 
responsible  for  tax  administration,  city,  oblast  and  raion  offices  operate  like  independent  tax 
administrations. Taxpayers are required to register and pay taxes to their regional administration. 
There  is  no  central  registry  of  taxpayers,  meaning  taxpayers  operating  across  several  regions 
must  register  in  each  region,  obtain  distinct  tax  identification  numbers,  and  pay  taxes  to  each 
regional administration according to their activity in that region. Further, reporting lines between 
the different levels of tax authority are muddied by the regular interference of local government 
officials, because state tax authorities also collect local taxes, which are deposited in the local 
government's accounts. 
 
4. 
The  tax  collection  system  in  Tajikistan  is  largely  paper-based,  with  the  exception  of 
some government and donor-supported initiatives to introduce limited automation. For instance, 
software  for  VAT  collection  has  been  developed  to  track  VAT  invoices.  However,  due  to 
resource constraints, this has been implemented in only six of 68 inspectorates. Likewise, the 
LTI has developed its own system, but much remains to be improved. 
 
5. 
Prospects for 2009. Between 2006 and 2008, tax revenues have on average increased 
by about 44%. However, the economic slowdown and reduced migrant remittances in 2009 are 
expected to significantly affect tax revenues. From January to April 2009, actual tax collections 
were 16.7% below the target. In May 2009, rates for the VAT were reduced from 20% to 18%, 
and for the profit tax from 25% to 15%. The Government anticipates a shortfall in tax revenues 
of  TJS551.3  million  (equivalent  to  13%  of  original  budget  estimates)  for  2009.  Tax  revenue 
growth (formerly forecast at 30% for 2009) has been sharply reduced to 13%, significantly below 
the prior years' average. VAT collection is expected to fall short by nearly TJS380 million due to 
weak consumer spending. The crisis will cause personal income and corporate profits to decline, 
and income and profit tax collection forecasts have been revised downward by TJS86.2 million. 
The  economic  slowdown  will  also  discourage  imports,  and  this  will  likely  reduce  revenue  from 
customs  duties  and  excise  taxes  on  foreign  goods.  Similarly,  low  commodity  prices  for  cotton 
and aluminum are expected to reduce the sales tax collected from sales of these commodities.

Credibility  of  the  Budget.  The  PEFA  assessment  gave  positive  ratings  for  aggregate 
revenue and expenditures. Revenue estimates were consistently exceeded, and this contributed 
to the higher-than-planned expenditures, which were kept within 15% of planned expenditures.

revenues  did  not  follow  proper  procedures.  The  assessment  also  found  that  significant 
reallocation within the budget occurred, which compromises budget credibility. Finally, the PEFA 
assessment found that the absence of a commitment control system weakened the monitoring 
of expenditure arrears. 
 
4. 
Comprehensiveness  and  Transparency.  Budget  documentation  was  found  to  be 
comprehensive and intergovernmental fiscal transfers were assessed as transparent. However, 
other  indicators  fared  poorly.  The  budget  classification,  while  following  the  International 
Monetary Fund's 1986 Government Finance Statistics Manual, does not have an administrative 
classification.  This  reduced  the  accountability  of  administrative  units.  The  PEFA  assessment 
also  identified  existence  of  sizable  quasi-fiscal  activities  that  increased  fiscal  risk.  Likewise, 
public  access  to  information  was  limited  and  information  provided  tended  to  be  partial  and 
incomplete.

Policy-Based  Budgeting.  The  budget  calendar  was  found  to  be  broadly  followed,  but 
the PEFA assessment found that issues regarding the detailed organization of the process and 
related  internal  deadlines  remain.  There  were  also  institutional  and  systemic  weaknesses  that 
hampered the linkage between policies and the budget. Further, capital budgeting was found to 
be fragmented, and needed to be integrated with recurrent expenditures.

weaknesses  in  the  predictability  and  control  of  budget  execution.  On  the  revenue  side,  there

expenditure  side,  public  payroll  controls  were  found  to  be  weak.  Procurement  reforms,  while 
initiated, still needed to be institutionalized. Internal audit was also found to be inadequate.

(iii) the social pillar underlines the Government's commitment to improve (a) basic social services in education, health, water

Tajikistan  has  made  good  progress  in  poverty  reduction  in  recent  years  owing  to  stable  economic  growth.  However,  the

increasing unemployment and economic hardship on low-income households.

With  an  annual  per  capita  income  of  $795,  Tajikistan  is  the  poorest  country  in  Central  Asia.  Poverty  has  been  reduced

The poverty and social impact from the crisis will be direct and immediate. A 2007 ADB survey indicates that as many as 40%
